I had two purchased and the other is still working, and offers a fine comfortable cut of hair that my nose seems more anxious to grow hair than on the top of my head, but given the other one failed with such little use, I was disappointed given I normally have always been a Panasonic brand fan.
  11289. No problems so far except the double A battery doesn't seem to last very long.
  11290. Industrial strength because one of the hairs was long and gnarly and very resistant to other methods.
  11291. This is a well-made bathroom utensil, and is likely to last much longer than previous one I have bought.
  11292. Only negative is that it does go through batteries quickly, about every month or so with regular use.
  11293. This ear and nose hair trimmer barely runs--almost from the start, it slowed down and sounds as though the battery is low, but the battery is new.
  11294. I dropped my 15 year old Panasonic 'personal groomer' and the tip must have bent slightly because noise level increased and the cutting was not as good as before the fall.
  11295. I'm shocked.<br />Anyway..this little thing works very well.
  11296. so I don't have much to compare it to, but I think I would like the trim to be a little closer.
  11297. Construction feels a little sacrificed on this unit, it doesn't have a very robust feel to it, nor does it carry heft.
  11298. How can one purchase do so much for so little money.
  11299. This little trimmer really works well for trimming those pesky nose and ear hairs.
  11300. Not a game changer, but it works with a little patience.
  11301. This little jewel really does the job.
  11302. The single AA battery gets tired fast and isn't really powerful enough to demolish ear and nose hair.
  11303. After the first use I took the cutting head off to clean it and everything came apart.
  11304. but I really like the potential of this little product.
  11305. I have never had a trimmer remove as much hair as this one does with such little (NO) pain.
  11306. first i thought that i had weak batteries but putting in new one did not help.
  11307. They do a very good job cutting hair although one must move slowly
  11308. it's as good or bad as others I have purchased,<br />Must
  11309. I'm not sure why it crapped out, it's cheap and not worth my time to warranty.<br
  11310. Don't be afraid to put it against your noise \\"walls.\\" The last trimmer I had cut them, but this one is elegant and efficient, never missing a hair.

  99. I've had an ancient Panasonic trimmer for, well, ever. With replacement blades and nose assembly no longer available, I was due, overdue, for an update. The good: Old unit wasn't waterproof, new one not only is, but is much easier to clean with its flow through cutter head feature. Cutters also act on the end of the unit, yielding faster and more consistent results. It is also much quieter in operation, which makes trimming ear hair possible without destroying your hearing.<br /><br />The not quite as good: Old unit was easy on the battery, I had one alkaline last for years and the one that's in it is only the third I've ever had to put into it. New one seems to be harder on the battery, take more juice to work, so I'll be surprised if a brand new battery lasts 6 months. New one is significantly larger, but that also makes it easier to grasp, so sort of a trade off.<br /><br />Build quality is excellent, as one expects from Panasonic.<br /><br />Bottom line: I was overdue for an update and I'm pleased with this choice.

  119. I feel really old having to say I &#34;love&#34; this nose and ear hair trimmer, but it isn't my first of this kind of grooming tool so I can say it is a good unit. What makes it work so well, I think, is that the design allows for flow through blade cleaning without disassembly. 'So after each use it is simple and quick enough to just twist open the cleaning port, shoot some clean cold tap water through it, give a shake, and put it away. Also, the cutting head has notches to allow hair to enter both on the top of the tip and from the sides. That makes 'blind&#34; trimming, like in the outer ear, easier and quicker and more effective. I've been using this unit for about a year now and the batter is still good; since motors drain batteries quite quickly, and I use this cutter at least once a month, I'd say that's pretty good.

  285. Sad I even need one, getting old sucks! LOL. This works pretty well. For nose hairs,change the batteries at even the slightest hint of loss of power (a lower pitched &#34;hum&#34;) because if you don't, the blade will pull, instead of cut, the hair. Trust me if you don't listen for it, you WILL feel a hair pulled instead of cut, and you WILL immediately change the batteries. I'm teaching you this, so you might not have to feel that torture. They say these devices, like my battery powered toothbrush, have circuitry that just cuts out the motor entirely if it senses low voltage. But I can tell you that, much like my battery powered toothbrush, I can audibly hear, and feel, the motor losing power...so that stuff is bunk.

  334. I had an earlier version of this trimmer that lasted for a decade, so I had no hesitation in going to Panasonic again. I knew when I took it out of the box that I was in for disappointment. The earlier model felt solid, well-built and lasted quite a long time. The difference in materials and build quality is obvious. I guess they don't want them to last a decade anymore. More money in their pockets if you have to replace it frequently. Mine lasted for about a week. Then, it began acting possessed. I can get it to work on occasion if I unscrew the bottom cap and play with the positioning of the battery, but even then the RPMs rev up and down, the blade makes a grinding sound and the unit puts off a strange odor. I wish Husqvarna or Honda made a nose hair trimmer.

  425. First off, this is my first and only nose trimmer. It works amazing. I was using an attachment to my Remington (not an actual nose trimmer attachment) and it was ok but only got the long hairs. After using this one, I will never go back to the attachment. It got every hair in my nose, and I trimmed my goatee with precision and ease. Be sure to read all the warnings first. I made sure not to press hard on my face or nose to avoid potential bleeding. The cleaning drain is pretty cool. I follow the instructions and twist of cap to help dry faster. My only wish, and therefore one less star, is that it was rechargeable. It uses one battery and seems to last a while but I think I will invest in more rechargeable batteries from energizer or Duracell, etc...

It gets to hair that other ones I have used had a harder time reaching. Perhaps of its shape and slender form it can get into those more recessed areas. My only issue, and I need to figure this out, is that it seems to have more energy when I use a regular battery. When I use a rechargeable one, even right from the charger, it doesn't seem to sound as strong. May be a perception issue on my end. I will need to check it out further. But even with that rechargeable battery it does get the job done. Great product, easy to use, slender and so simple to clean.

  462. I received this trimmer just about four months ago and after using it several times a week on both my nose and ear hair I'm happy to say I'm still on the original battery I installed the day I got this.<br /><br />The trimmer does a good job of cutting close. I recommend using a mirror, especially on the nose or you will miss things. I've only had it grab hair and yank instead of trim once or twice which is far better than the last trimmer I purchased.<br /><br />This trimmer is sold as Wet/Dry but I see no evidence of o-rings in the battery compartment to ensure a water tight seal. I would not use this in the shower or allow it to be submerged in water.<br /><br />The 'Vortex Cleaning System' the trimmer boasts is just an open/close vent at the base of the cutter head that allows you (with the trimmer on) to run it under a stream of water for superior cleaning capability. The instructions even remind you to mind the position of the exit port to avoid splashing water all over. I've tried the Vortex system under two sink faucets and a bathtub faucet. None of which produced more than a trickle of water out the exit port and I really wasn't impressed with how clean it left the unit. It was far easier and you can get the trimmer much cleaner by disassembling it and cleaning it with the small brush it comes with. This task is easily accomplished. Disassembly and reassembly are a breeze.<br /><br />All in all it's a good trimmer that does it's job well and uses little power so you'll save money on batteries.
  463. Very quiet, no muss, no fuss. I don't know what battery life will be like, but the trimmer works very well for me.<br /><br />I tried multipurpose machines, but this does a better job.

  503. After having another brand's hair trimmer break after literally minutes of use, I returned the broken trimmer to the store and went online to buy this. Nice build quality, well-designed, and best of all it actually works great.
  504. I've had several trimmers of this sort over the years. The Panasonic Vortex is generally similar to just about any other. It does a very good job eliminating those fine hairs that crop up in the nostrils and in and around the ears. However, its promotion statements claims that it can also be used as a facial hair trimmer. I strongly doubt this. Nothing about the size, weight or sharpness of the device's blades indicates to me that it could effectively used on the beard area. What distinguishes this product from any number of similar ones is its ergonomic design. The size, shape and materials used in the construction of the Panasonic Vortex fits comfortably in the hand and makes it easy to store away. The manufacturer also claims that its water-resistant, making it capable of use in the shower, though I haven't tried this myself. Given that this product costs and functions about the same as any other I would chose it over others based on its better design qualities.
  505. Very nice, should have gotten this years ago.
  506. This trimmer works really well and the battery last a very long time (of course you don't need to use it too often). I use this on my nose, ears, and my eyebrows (edges and between) and it works for all. You just have to get the right angle for each application. It does not get that dirty in the first place, but it cleans easily too.
  507. I bought this one (Remington NE-3 Precision Wet/Dry Rotary Nose and Ear Trimmer - http://www.amazon.com/Remington-NE-3-Precision-Rotary-Trimmer/dp/B00005B6ZM/ref=cm_cr-mr-title) on Amazon and it was terrible. (see my review) This one is 100% better. Much easier to clean. The motor doesn't drag when you turn it on. Does a much better job. The parts don't fall out. Much quieter. Inexpensive and worth the money. Even looks better (although I really don't care about that, but you might). If you need a trimmer, this is just as good or better than the others I've tried, for less money.

  521. This is my first experience owning an electric Nose/Facial Hair Trimmer. Out the box, the trimmer feels nice and lightweight, but the material and build quality is good. The unit uses one AA battery. There is an attachable cap and detachable blade that can be removed and cleaned. There is also an included little brush. This unit has a nice amount of power and is great for trimming off nose hairs that might be difficult to reach and remove. Off course the unit can also be used to trim and neaten your eyebrow and facial hair. The only drawback is that this device does not have some type of recharging station. So if you use it often, you'll be needing plenty of AA's. Otherwise this is a solid trimmer at a decent price.

It uses a single AA battery, which I haven't had to replace in the last 2 months with occasional use.<br /><br />All that is pretty standard for a decent trimmer, but what sets this unit apart is that it washable! This is a pretty nice feature to have. Instead of trying to tap or scrape out the hairs, you just open up the top and rinse everything out.   589. I have fairly large nostrils. I like to keep that prominence to a minimum. Every so often I would notice hairs both long and short poking out around the edges, which I would hedge back with scissors, fingertips (did I say that I have large nostrils?) and tweezers. While I don't mind a good cry or sneeze or two, I needed something modern, something hygienic, and something that would keep me from plucking my nose hairs in public. Enter this neat little trimmer, the Panasonic ER-GN30-K. At first, I did not think that it could possibly trim the finer and shorter hairs. This trimmer is able to get deep up in my schnoz and clean the edges well. The blades seem set back just a bit too far for short hair, but it gets the job done well. After prolonged use, the tip warms up a bit. Not blazing, just warm. When the battery begins to lose charge the trimmer is less effective. It is tough to tell when that is happening until you realize you have to work harder to get the job done. This is a only minor negative for me. I think I can extend this recommendation to beaks big and small. Good job Panasonic!

  630. This trimmer arrived quickly as was estimated. It is packaged in a sealed plastic container which can easily be opened if there is a road crew nearby that would lend you their pneumatic drill. Along with the trimmer is a tiny brush, a user guide and some other paperwork of no consequence (to me). It has an attractive appearance and is easily gripped with a comfortable hand fitting. The bottom portion slides off to allow the insertion of a single AA battery (not included). This is the most quiet trimmer I have ever owned. It performs very well in trimmming nose hair, which is its only purpose for me. When finished trimming it will stand up on its end to minimize counter space if that is a factor. I would give this trimmer more then 5 stars if it were possible to do so. This is a winner.
  631. If you're looking for this kind of trimmer, this works great. I've used it for a couple of months, on one set of batteries still, it just does the job.

  645. Boy, getting old sure does suck...Never thought I'd be writing a review on a nose/ear hair trimmer. But, as I get older, I seem to be growing hair in all the areas that I would prefer not to. In addition, losing hair in areas that i would like to retain hair. But enough about me. This Panasonic hair trimmer works very well. It's very powerful. I was worried that it would pull the hair more then trim, but that's definitely not the case. The unit is constructed very well. I haven't test the wet aspect per se, but I have rinsed it off for cleaning purposes. Still works like a charm. I don't have a reason into going into pros/cons on this since it works as I had hoped it to. Nothing really to complain about. With regards to the practice of trimming ear or nose hair, the one recommendation that I have is to do it continuously. If you've never done it before, expect to be quite uncomfortable the first time you do it. At least for my nose, I could feel the trimmed hairs for a couple of days afterwards. Especially when I went to itch my nose. Also, the feeling of shorter hairs in your nose will give the sensation that there's something in your nose. Strange, really. Anyway, after continuous use, I no longer have those feelings. Not sure if my nose is just numb to the feeling or what. I would definitely recommend this to those hairy nose and ear people. As myself!

To test it I ran it straight through the corner of my eyebrow (lol). I'm not kidding. It did not leave a clear streak through it. Like, it didn't look like it does when someone has a scar through their eyebrow or if you were to run a clipper through your eyebrow (or straight razor). Even after multiple tries. I don't get it. How is that okay? It doesn't give a satisfying cut feel and noise when you run it through your nose. I will do so like four or five times before I just sigh and give up because it's not cutting any more hair after its first pass through. You can press it very hard against the skin and hear a view more hairs getting zapped but even when applying way more strength then you ever should with this it doesn't cut that much more hair. How is this so far ahead of all the other similar products in terms of reviews ?

Problem solved. (I suspect that many of the 1-star reviewers ranting about how their trimmer \\"just stopped working\\" might not be cleaning it after every use, as suggested by the manual, or not cleaning it thoroughly. Your mileage may vary.) My experience with the trimmer has been very good. Much safer and more effective than trying to use scissors!

I have a sharper image trimmer that uses a C size battery....it seems under-powered as compared to this Panasonic unit with a AA alkaline battery.<br /><br />ON rechargeable batteries: They are not recommended as Alkaline will give it the power it needs...however, I found that this trimmer works just FINE with a Eneloop battery and is just as strong as with an Alkaline battery. I have been using it with an Eneloop for a while now and have not experienced any loss of power or slow downs. Your experience may vary.<br /><br />Great unit, priced a bit higher then others but worth the extra $. 5/5 for me.

  958. The small diameter and smooth surface makes it somewhat hard to grasp. I've had problems with iTV remote and ordered the leather sleeve on Amazon so you have a point of reference. Hence, I believe the reason for some reviews indicating dropping and damage. So if you are prone to dropping things go with the larger diameter Panasonic unit (I believe performance will be similar).<br /><br />Performance was very good. I compared it to a older design (that I still have) of a Panasonic nose hair trimmer and you could see the results since you needed to clean it out versus flushing. I would clean out the old Panasonic unit with a moistened Q-tip and you see your results. I cleaned out the ER-GN30K using Q-tip method versus brushing or flushing out and was amazed how well and how fine cuts were.<br /><br />Just be careful in handling...smooth surface and small diameter makes it prone to slipping and dropping. Hence, the four stars.<br /><br />By the way, son was also impressed by results. He was using a pair of scissors (embroidery), which I told him is not the way to go...
  959. I'll make this short and sweet... I've tried at least twelve different models over the years (including that huge trimmer from Sharper Image) and this works better than all of them put together. No pulling. Easy to clean. And thoroughly effective. Hope it lasts (i.e. that the blades don't get too dull, too soon). Come to think of it, though ... for the price, if it only lasts six months it would still be worth it.

  964. I don't know if this happens to everyone, but as soon as you hit middle age you start growing long hairs in odd places. They grow out of your ears. Your nose. On the ears. You get bushy eyebrows like Andy Rooney. Finally you get hair growth in oddball places I would rather not mention. Needless to say, whether you are vain or not this aberrant growth can lead to some difficulty with your interpersonal relationships.<br /><br /> This is where this Panasonic Vortex hair trimmer comes in. It is small, portable, battery operated, and gets rid of those oddball hairs, wherever they may be. If you have a close contact with people job like me and do a lot of travelling, this unit is for you. It quickly and efficiently cuts off that unwanted hair with no problems. It is safe. It makes you look younger. It is easy to stuff in your bag. It is durable. It is a great adjunct to a shaver and gets places a shaver won't.<br /><br /> Although not a permanent solution, it is a lot cheaper and safer than a visit to the dermatologist for laser therapy and safer and more comfortable than electrolysis or plucking. I give this little gadget five stars. It saves a little aggravation and only needs to be used weekly or as needed. And it is easy on batteries so you will not go broke maintaining it.

  1035. I bought this for the obvious reasons and after 2 weeks of use, I can say it has it's ups and downs. The first time you use this, is slightly unnerving putting a spinning blade into your nose even knowing it can't really hurt you. However, after the first few seconds, you realize it's not that bad. The blades come fairly sharp already and more or less cut the hair easily. Sometimes with a thicker follicle, it can tug on the hair as the blade struggles to cut it. I think so far it has done this maybe 3 or 4 times with me. My biggest complaint is the device leaves stubble maybe 1mm high in your nose and if you squeeze your nose to stop a sneeze or when you're swimming, the stubble can be quiet painful believe it or not. After all, human hair is stronger than copper of the same diameter. As a result, you could have dozens of little hairs stabbing the inside of your nose. Other than that, the device could be a little stronger but what can you expect from a single AA battery power source. I'm a little hesitant to use this in the shower as it advertises but when I do, I will update this review. So far for the price though, it's worth it.

  1187. I bought this trimmer after my barber started asking me if I wanted my ear hair trimmed. He wasn't joking around, he was actually offering it as a service. I hadn't noticed my ear hair because it was light in color, but more recently it's been growing more and more. I always used scissors, which is foolish and a waste of time. I was doing it all wrong.<br /><br />For everyone else who is doing it all wrong, STOP. Go out and buy this trimmer. Someone else has made this product so that you no longer have to stick scissors up your nose and into your years. Throw your scissors away, and buy this trimmer. It costs the same as two bottles of hipster microbrew.<br /><br />For the price, I wasn't expecting much. I was actually surprised to see a brand name trimmer being sold at this price so I jumped on it. The trimmer itself is nothing fancy, but I was quite impressed by the build quality and how everything snapped together nicely. The battery compartment has a nice tight seal with a rubber o-ring to prevent water from getting inside. You don't have to worry about a splash of water causing the trimmer to rust or otherwise malfunction.<br /><br />As for the functionality; it does what it says, at a brilliant price, with respectable efficiency. My only worry was that a trimmer would yank/pull hairs out of my nose, but I am glad to say that there is no pulling, and there is no yanking of hairs. The hairs are cut without the slightest hint of pulling. You basically feel nothing. You only know it is working because you can hair the offending hairs being sliced with the utmost efficiency.<br /><br />Now that I have this thing, I'd like to use it on other people. Hard to avoid the temptation. I see people on the subway and bus, and I want to stick this trimmer into their ears. You will too.

  1283. I purchased the Panasoic ER-GN30-K Vortex trimmer to replace a Remington trimmer that finally-and mercifully--bit the dust. I absolutely HATED the Remington, from it's design to it's performance. The Panasonic, by contrast, is very nicely designed and surprisingly well-built for the price. Most importantly, it simply works great on both my nose-hair and ear hair, which, at my age, are a constant issue. In addition, Amazon was great, as it almost always is, in getting this delivered to me in 2 days time. The only negative I can think of was in getting the product out of it's damnable packaging. Bear in mind that the AA battery needed to operate the trimmer is not included. This did not either surprise me or present any problems to me personally, but just thought I'd pass that along. I highly recommend this product to anyone looking for a very well-made and highly effective trimmer at a good price.

  1297. This is the first time I've used a trimmer and I love it. Wasn't sure what to expect, whether it would hurt or if I would be sneezing all day. None of that happened. The trimmer is:<br /><br />- very easy to set up<br />- requires a AA battery (not included)<br />- washable<br />- operates at an acceptable noise level (low humming sound)<br />- gets rid of hair with no pull or tuck feeling<br /><br />I used this for my nose and ears and it worked great. The rounded cap on top has a blade on the inside, the blade is placed slightly lower than the tip of the cap. This helps avoid any skin tucks, making it completely safe to use. There is a small opening in the top cap that can be exposed by rotating the head of the trimmer. The opening here is what makes the trimmer washable, it lets water in to wash the blade and also drains it out.<br /><br />Haven't tried other trimmers so I can't really compare but this one worked just fine and I'm sticking to it.

This is, most devices like it made in &#34;China&#34;, are, a cheap product but does get good reviews... however the idea of trying to trim about one's ears, well this won't fit in the folds of an 'ear' any easier than along the sides of a nasal cavity and you get a 'weedy' look of partially trimmed ear hair... unless you want to braid 'em I would suggest a product that 'protrudes' and has 'an edge' with which you can carefully trim hair far more deeply recessed or in ear crevasses.   1424. UPDATE: JAN 20, 2014<br />It has now been exactly 2 months since I submitted my contact information to Panasonic for warranty service. No one has contacted me from their company. This trimmer has a 2 year warranty period, I consider this to be consumer fraud. Absolutely appalling customer service. That being said, this is a really cheap trimmer. I went to the dollar store and bought a trimmer that was three dollars. It is the best trimmer I've ever had!<br /><br />When I first got this trimmer it worked exceptionally well. In fact, the first couple of times were amazing. That's when things started going downhill. After a couple of months the trimmer started performing really poorly. My nose hair would get trapped in the trimmer and the only way to get it out was to pull the trimmer really hard and to rip out the hair. This is an EXTREMELY painful process. I thought that perhaps the batters were low and there wasn't enough power for the blades to cut the hair. But even after replacing the batteries it would still trap my hair. I can no long use this trimmer. I've contacted Panasonic customer support through their website over a week ago and no one has responded to me yet. I ordered this product about 6 months ago and I'm still within my 2 year warranty period.
  1425. This is a great little trimmer. I've tried several others and none have done as well of a job on both nose hair and ear hair as this one. I would certainly reccommend this item.
  1426. My husband loves the hair trimmer. He used it the first day we received it, and it cut excellently. Would recommend the product to others.

  1429. This is a great trimmer! I can't speak much for it being used as a trimmer for the ear, but for the nose it's working really well. As I have gotten older, I find myself having to trim my nose hair much more often, about once a month. With the old blade style of electric trimmer I would always dread it because because I had to stick the blades all the way up to the offending hairs in my nose. Often it wouldn't get those long hairs were sticking out the most. Yuck! And I had to remove these hairs the old fashioned way, using my fingernails. Never a very pleasing thing to have to do! With this one you just slip in and run it around a little, and it does the job. It's much faster, too. I give it five stars!

Alkaline battery lasts a long time, but I'd recommend a rechargeable battery to cut waste. It doesn't trim eyebrows, like the Remington could, but I find this a minor inconvenience, considering the great job it does otherwise.<br />Bonus: Trimmed hair is contained within the cutter housing, doesn't get all over your nostrils etc., so you feel/are clean after using.   1677. I purchased my unit in May 2012. I love the way it trims, but after a couple of uses, it started falling apart, showing all the symptoms customers mention in the 1-star rating section. The \\"rocket shaped\\" part with the blades attached becomes loose and starts to bounce around. It always takes me a few minutes to get it back on just the right way in order to continue to trim. Well, today I did something different. I took a flashlight and noticed a tiny spring inside the \\"rocket\\" part. I removed it by using the wire of a paperclip and then put the blade part back on the unit. If you push it too far down, it won't rotate due to the built-in \\"stopper\\". However, if you place it about half way down, it will rotate just fine. So far, it's working like a charm, no more bouncing off or around! Let's see, how long it lasts :)

  1767. UPDATE:Recent one lasted two and a half years. Still the best, but you have to take good care of it and gently take apart,put together.<br /><br />I found this trimmer to be (by far) the easiest to use with the closest cut. The design is the key--the rounded top allows the blades to get really close and to safely and easily navigate ears and nose.<br /><br />That said, i have now gone through three of these. The internal motor mechanism is really glitchy, and will sometimes just stop working. (To be clear, even when the blade head is removed, the shaft will not spin.) When this has happened, i have coaxed more life out of them by (carefully) striking against my palm (or harder surface, damn it) with the unit ON, which seems to shake away the glitch for awhile, months even.<br /><br />Panasonic had a model number previous to this one, which was otherwise the exact same (on the outside). That first one lasted me almost a year before stopping. I had it replaced, and the second one lasted about six months. When i returned the second one, Hammacher replaced it with a Wahl; likely because of the stated issue. Unfortunately, the Wahl (and other non-rounded head models) cut no closer than my beard trimmer. Not it. I have also tried the thin reciprocating linear blade trimmers, but found myself chasing after each individual hair and that just didn't cut it for me either.<br /><br />So, i found this Panasonic newer model number on Amazon; still glitchy, still the best trimmer.<br /><br />The fact that the motor glitch could and should be repaired means no more than 3 stars. However, i don't want it discontinued, so i promise to give it 4 stars when Panasonic repairs this issue. (I would only give it 5 stars after years of use.) Until then, i will continue to return/replace these as needed.

  1855. First of all, I've been seeing ads for rotary nose hair trimmers all my life and when I was young I thought - how ridiculous. How hairy can someone's nose or ears get? Well, at 50 I am beginning to get a glimpse of why you want these things.<br /><br />I've always tried to find a little private time several times a week to yank both ear and nose bush, but as time has marched on, I began to realize I was losing the war. My barber made some light hearted cracks about how men when reaching a certain age just start sprouting the uglies. Of course, the eyebrows overgrow a little too, but that problem isn't as bad - yet. Lucky I'll have these trimmers around.<br /><br />I don't know any other men who own a trimmer like this - the men in my family seem to just consider tufts of wayward hair coming out their head holes to enhance character or something - so I was on my own. My only personal experience trying one once - well, it was awful. Many years ago I gently raised one into a nostril where it set about yanking out every nostril hair it could grab. Very painful.<br /><br />So after reading reviews and seeing this as a top seller for an affordable price, I went for it. Two days later, with some trepidation, I put it to the test. It gently and quietly went to work civilizing and youth-ifying my nose and ears. Perfect. Easy to operate, easy to clean, and totally painless. And quiet, too, which was something I hadn't thought about but I appreciate.<br /><br />We'll see how it holds up over time, but at its extremely affordable price, I won't mind too much if it konks out in 18 months or something.<br /><br />So, gentlemen, if you're 50 or over I suggest you look in the mirror - really look and be honest - and if you think your situation is beyond tweezing, buy this thing. It's fantastic.

I'm going to keep it because it ultimately gets the job done and none of the others get better reviews, but it's not great.<br /><br />Reminds me of my beard trimmers: each time I need new one, the latest models are worse than the one before. If manufacturers would concentrate on mechanical quality over extra useless marketing settings, I'd be willing to pay much more $. You'd think with today's trend of (faux) authenticity and history (hipsters, safety razors, old-timey beards, small batch rye, etc), some manufacturers would get that there's a lot of $ to be made in quality construction. Alas not.

  2038. got what I wanted. works great. quick shipment. good quality and simple to use works just like it says it does. worthy choice and investment. god bless
  2039. FAST BLADE CUTS CLEANLY AND THOROUGHLY. Panasonic ER-GN30-K Vortex Wet/dry Nose and Facial Hair Trimmer . I LIKE IT GOOD!
  2040. Typical of these nose trimmers (which as I've moved into my 40s have become an necessity) is that they are cheaply manufactured to start out working well and work like crap--tugging dully, painfully at the larger nose hairs--after a few months. The Panasonic name doesn't at all symbolize product excellence like it once did. (Maybe they should have stuck with music and TVs?) I don't have any suggestions. I buy one of these pieces of s*** ever two or three months, since there isn't a monetarily viable option for purchasing replacement blades.<br /><br />I'd like to add that this one now buzzes when fully battery charged really fast when I hold it at one angle and really slow and grinding with a sound like a rusty electric can opener when I move it around. Sound like cheap Chinese-manufactured crap? Yep, that's exactly what this product is.

  2197. Like many guys who have been lots of years breathing in and out--I'm &#34;older&#34;--hair is going away where I want it to stay and growing in places that I don't want it to be. Those &#34;shouldn't be there&#34; hairy spots include my nostrils and virtually everywhere around and inside my ears. I don't want to look like a hobbit. Razors leave unsightly slice marks (and blood stains on my t-shirt). Straight clippers work in some areas but not inside my nose and ears.<br />This little clipper is great. It clips hair to 1/64&#34; while preventing cuts in the process. One AA battery powers the sucker instead of an internal battery that dies after a year or so and isn't replaceable. It's blade is titanium, cleans easily with water and is replaceable. I use it to trim my ear and nose hair and it does it perfect in less than a minute with no pain.<br />5- Very easy to clean. It is an electrical device but those compartments are well sealed inside. All you need is to switch it to wet mode (shown with a water tap sign) and put it under the water. It gets rid of all trimmed hair instantly.<br />6- It is a good quality item that has worked great after 18 months of weekly use.<br /><br />Normally, I like mentioning about the negative aspects of the items I review as well. However I can not find a good one in this case. May be one thing to mention is that it comes without protective casing or bags which I can not complain for the price. Besides, it can stand upright so can be put in a bathroom cabinet easily so it is not a big deal at all.<br /><br />Final words go to the price fluctuations on amazon website... I have seen its price skyrocketed to $23+shipping since I bought it. At the time of writing the review it is only available from third party vendors and that is probably the reason behind this unfair price increase. I think it will eventually fall down to the original price of $12-13 whenever it becomes available directly through amazon. so I suggest keeping an eye on the price before ordering it.

  2264. I'm getting older and hairy where I don't want to be. Plus I can't see as well close up.<br /><br />Ram this up the snout and give it a whirl and the nose hair gets plucked into the center and your sensitive nose will get a vibration that tickles like crazy.<br /><br />But it doesn't hurt.<br /><br />--------<br /><br />Update after 5 uses!!!!<br /><br />Ok, this tickling trouble is fixed, and wow does this tool do the job. I found out it was tickling because I was going too easy on it, worried it would dig into my skin or even worse bog down in my nose and get trapped in the hair. Getting this caught in a bunch of nose hair has obvious drawbacks. Big mistake being worried about that.<br /><br />The secret to using this wonder-tool in the nose is to jam it in there - hard - and ream it around. You can hear the hairs make noise as they are whacked off. Dig for the noise, and when you can't find any more noise doing a good 360-degree sweep of the perimeter, you are getting the job done, but good.<br /><br />After figuring out this secret, I could actually breathe easier, just like after porting the intake runners on a 70 Olds. Or installing a bigger foam cone filter on a restrictive factory air intake on an e36 BMW M3.<br /><br />The clean fresh, feeling of being able to feet a few more cubic feet of air per minute through the nose is worth more than the price of admission.<br /><br />They should bundle this with those one-the-nose strips that some athletes (used to??) use. A real power-combo.<br /><br />The only suggestion is to take it apart and clean it out. Each time. This is not a tool that good hygiene principles allow for occasional cleaning. But that's my OCD coming through.<br /><br />If you are hairy where you don't want to be -- above the neck, that is -- get it.
  2265. This is a nice compact device and it works well.
  2266. Great product, but I wanted to shed light on some of the issues others have had with the trimmer. Some are claiming that the device simply &#34;stops working&#34; after some amount of uses. I ran into the same scenario; it stopped working after I went to clean it one time. I noticed the motor would still spin without the blade in place and cap on, but wouldn't spin with those two pieces assembled. Took it apart again and noticed a curved piece of plastic in the chamber that holds the hair that was blocking the blade from moving freely. After struggling with it for a while trying to push it out of the chamber and back into it's slot on the side (where it looked like it should have gone), I tried installing the blade this time without putting it fully into the chamber, but resting the black plastic legs of the blade on top of this curved plastic piece, and reinstalling the cap. The product now works just fine again. As an engineer, I know an intuitive design, and this is not one of them. You must insert the blade into the cap, not the housing, before installing the cap back onto the body of the device. I hope this clears up confusion for some people who have had this problem.

  2288. Yes, I agree with most of the reviews--it's a pretty good trimmer for the money. But there's a catch. See, Panasonic says to replace the head on their nose-and-ear trimmers (i.e., the top part which houses the blade and can screw off) every 3 years. Ok, fine, you say--only they don't sell replacements! (Or at least if they do, I didn't make it past page 10 of their site's ridiculous 100+ pages of search results to find it.) Other sites sell replacement heads, but they generally cost more than even the fancy ER430 vacuum-model (which, thankfully, uses the same head as this one, so at least I can cannabilize this).<br /><br />So, lesson learned: If you ever DROP a Panny trimmer on anything harder than a giant pile of Charmin, you might as well throw it away. You probably bent the metal part at the top ever so slightly, and that will make the blade rattle, and you will never be able to align it again, and you will never find replacement blades at a fair price. Boo...

  2315. I purchased this trimmer because of its excellent reviews, but unfortunately, I can't recommend it based on my own experiences. The trimmer worked great right out of the box -- it operates quickly, efficiently, and surprisingly silently. There's no pain when the hair is cut, and it was easy to clean.<br /><br />Unfortunately, the blade on mine stopped cutting after about 4 1/2 months. I contacted customer service, and I was offered a replacement part at a cost that was more than what I spent on the trimmer itself. After consulting the other reviews, I would bet that the problem wasn't actually the blade -- those are expected to last for a few years -- but rather the motor wearing out (due to the failure of internal springs that operate the blades). However, even though the trimmer is under warranty, I'm not willing to spent the cost of shipping (which is more than half of the cost of the trimmer itself) to find out whether my hunch is true.<br /><br />This is basically a disposable product. I wouldn't mind having one on-hand to stuff into a travel bag in case of emergencies, but I'd never want to pay for another one. I'll be upgrading to a different brand next time.

  2346. Part of me hates this product. Not because it works poorly or broke fast, but mostly because I have to admit that I'm old enough to need a nose hair trimmer. Once I got past that rude awakening, I saw the product as the great little device it is. Look, it's made of plastic and uses a somewhat underpowered battery, but what do you want for less money than a movie ticket? When it comes to cutting hairs in your nose and ears, this thing kicks ass. The blade does a good job of cutting through hairs without snagging. You can hear the motor bog down a bit but it recovers fast. The blades are close enough to the foil to get the hairs nice and short without catching the skin inside your nose.<br /><br />I'm not crazy about the cleaning function, as it honestly doesn't work too well, and I considered dropping the review to five stars as a result, but for the price I can't bring myself to. I just twist open the top and rinse out the blades that way.<br /><br />There may be better trimmers with better construction and more power, but I honestly wouldn't pay an additional penny for them, because this one does everything I want it to. Also, when the day comes that it eventually breaks, I won't hesitate to buy another at the amazingly low price.<br /><br />Buy with confidence, this is one of those products you can save money on without sacrificing anything. If you have any questions, please ask in the comments. Cheers!

  2420. There’s a trade-off involved with this trimmer. My previous trimmer, which broke, had a straight blade with a comb-like blade guard, which left exposed nose hair stubble and irritated tender skin inside my nostrils. This trimmer, with its rotating blade and circular guard, doesn’t irritate, and leaves no visible hair remnants inside my nose. My nostrils haven’t looked this good since before I started growing facial hair.<br /><br />But the round surface makes this trimmer sketchier for edging my mustache. I had difficulty making it travel a straight line along my upper lip, and accidentally cut a notch over my philtrum, which will have to grow back out. Methinks I’ll have to go back to maintaining my mustache with a razor and the little scissors, which is a pain in the kiester, but at least works right, consistently, the first time.<br /><br />This trimmer’s curved design and rubberized grip make it easy to use, and the narrow, rounded head reaches into nostrils with minimum irritation. (I’ve been fortunate enough to avoid ear hair so far, so I can’t speak to that. Yet.) The Panasonic people apparently designed this device with ergonomic principles in mind. I appreciate both the ease of use, and the clean, professional look it gives my admittedly hairy nose.<br /><br />On balance, I prefer this trimmer over my last one. As much as I liked how that one simplified mustache gardening, it left my nose tender, inflamed, and unacceptably hairy. With this one, my face looks spit-shined and ready for anything. Men interested in looking upwardly mobile and competent should seriously consider this well-designed, effective trimmer to keep natural hair in check.

It has a short in it because if you tap it against your palm and it will sometimes start working again. I am not a stickler, I know some electronics are going to be bad out of the millions that are produced. But I was kind of annoyed that it isn't even a year old and I have to pay to ship it back myself, no prepaid label provided by Panasonic. It worked quite well when it did work, was very happy with it. Just disappointed that Panasonic didn't stand behind their product (I just bought it less than 4 months ago) and provide a prepaid shipping label so I didn't have to deal with it.<br /><br />EDIT UPDATE:<br /><br />Went ahead and paid 3-4 dollars to ship it to Panasonic, figured I might as well since a new one of any brand would cost more than that and I really liked it when it did work. Took about two months to get the replacement back from Panasonic and guess what? Yep, it worked a few times and is now dead (it was brand new in retail packaging). While I was waiting for this one to get back I bought a cheapo China no-name brand trimmer for under $4 shipped and it's still working.

  2592. The first one broke with 3 weeks. I suspect there is quality issue with the blades. I opened up the blades to clean with the included brush and put it back. It started making a loud buzzing sound and it wouldn't cut anymore. After several attempts and online research, I concluded that the blades are spring loaded and these springs wear down fast due to quality issues. When the trimmer is used, the edges of the blades brush against the cover and make the loud buzzing sound.<br />Amazon sent me another one and this one is working good so far. I will probably try not to use the brush to clean the blades with this one.<br />The panasonic website lists the replacement blades at a higher cost than the amazon price for the trimmer. The Panasonic warranty claim isn't the best since they expect the broken unit to be mailed at our cost to them for them to honor their warranty. On a $13 trimmer, that doesn't much sense.

  2832. This works well and is cheap, however the blade assembly is pretty cheap.<br />Due to that, it might be that yours stop working like mine did. It looks like it doesn't turn on anymore, and there is no motor noise even with a fresh battery.<br /><br />If that happens, it means the blade is stuck (when this happens it makes absolutely no noise so its hard to figure out its in fact stuck).<br /><br />You can unstuck it by unscrewing the head (the whole black area is the head and can be unscrewed by hand, counter clockwise. its easy)<br /><br />Be careful not to lose the blade assembly (its a plastic piece with a double tiny blade mounted on it).<br />Blow in the head, blades, etc to clean it up.<br />With the blade outside the device, turn the device on and make sure it makes noise/the motor turns on.<br />Reassemble, enjoy ;)

  2860. As a man(?) who doesn't grow much facial hair, I don't have to shave very often. And because I have an ugly mug, I often go months without looking in the mirror. This created a problem. I used to go to important events with a small number of 3 inch hairs protruding from chin and upper lip. I can't blame them for not hiring me. I wouldn't hire a goat, either. Because goats can't talk, and thus make terrible customer service representatives.<br /><br />But I found a solution to my problem. You see, I discovered the joy that is the Panasonic ER-GN30-K Vortex Wet/dry Nose and Facial Hair Trimmer, Black. It's small enough to fit in my backpack (right between my Phoenix Wright manga and my Nintendo DSi XL), which means I can take it with me and remove disgusting hair and debris from my nose, face, ears, and neck any time I need to.<br /><br />Additionally, it lasts a long time in a single battery. I've had it for several months and have not had to change the battery. I figure at the rate I use it, it will last me about 97 years. Thank goodness, 'cause I doubt we'll still be using AA batteries when I'm 127 years old.<br /><br />Of course, the Panasonic ER-GN30-K Vortex Wet/dry Nose and Facial Hair Trimmer, Black does have its flaws. For one, it only effective on small amounts of hair. So for trimming beard and nose hair, it's perfect. But it took me about 30 minutes to shave my whole face with it. At that rate, it would take me a couple of days to shave my back. I made this handy chart for reference:<br /><br />Hair Source | Time to shave<br />-------------------------------------<br />Nose | 90 seconds<br />Beard | 5 minutes<br />Face | 30 minutes<br />Back | 2 days<br />Robin Williams' arms | Unknown<br /><br />The Panasonic ER-GN30-K Vortex Wet/dry Nose and Facial Hair Trimmer, Black also tends to get a little warm after a minute or two. Not like oven hot, or surface of the sun hot, or even pop-tart filling hot. Just warm.<br /><br />By the way, don't put this thing in your ear canal. It sounds like being attacked by a hive of Mike Tysons.<br /><br />In short, this is a great product for trimming nose and face hair. It is a mediocre product for shaving your back. It is a poor product for protecting you from bears.<br /><br />The end.s thing in your ear canal. It sounds like being attacked by a hive of Mike Tysons.<br /><br />In short, this is a great product for trimming nose and face hair. It is a mediocre product for shaving your back. It is a poor product for protecting you from bears.<br /><br />The end.

At times, you can feel the hair being pulled but it's nowhere close to the feel of the hair being pulled out. It's the same as the shaver, the actual moving parts(the blades) don't touch the surface, so even if you push it against the skin, it won't hurt the skin.<br />Even if you understand it in your head, you'll still be hesitant to stick that metal in your nose at first.<br />I'm still on the process of getting used to it and becoming more comfortable of the idea.<br />You'll probably won't use it as often as a shaver, so the battery juice last a long time but I still use a rechargeable because I already have it and keep them ready for many other things I have. Even if you decide to use Alkaline, it won't be as wasteful.<br />Cleaning it is much easier than cleaning an electric shaver. If you have ever spent time trying to get the hairs out of your nose or your ears the old fashioned way, then you know that those hairs are connected to every nerve in your face. Fortunately, Panasonic has found a much better way to get those hairs with no pain. The battery life is a bit lacking, but it is powered by a single battery. he biggest feature is the fact that it is waterproof, and able to be fully submerged in water. This is important for those in a hurry, and take care of all of their grooming in the shower. No need to keep this on the counter, hope you do not forget, and get somewhere when that nose hair starts to tickle your lip. The convenience of being able to use this in the shower really separates this from other brands. Clean up, no problem. It is waterproof. Run it under the sink, and that is it.   3003. I had a Panasonic trimmer that I bought from Sharper Image that I used for years. It worked great, but eventually died. When I looked for a replacement I found out that they didn't make that model anymore. At the time the reviews of the Panasonic trimmers indicated that they weren't as good as they used to be, so I bought a Mangroomer one. The Mangroomer worked well enough but only lasted a year or so (water from rinsing it leaked through the seal into the motor and battery compartment and everything got corroded). I bought this new model Panasonic about a month ago and found it to be as good as the Panasonics of the past. The motor is very quiet (much quieter that the Mangroomer) and they have added a little drain hole at the bottom of the base. This drain hole is important so that water can drain when running water over the cutting head to clean it. The cutting heads stay cleaner and I haven't had to disassemble it to clean the cutting heads, as I had to with past trimmers without the drain hole. These trimmers are all pretty much the same. The quiet motor and the little drain hole make this one a little better than the others that I have used. Only time will be the judge on the durability issue, but overall I think this is well worth the couple of dollars more that this trimmer cost me.

  3048. With advanced age has come a flourishing but unwelcome crop of nose hair, which if left untrimmed starts to tickle annoyingly. Against this growth, for years I used a Remington \\"cross-cut\\" trimmer. It worked, but this Panasonic rotary trimmer works better and is easier and quicker to use. It does not, however, completely replace scissors for hairs that lie flat (and tickle the most). On the other hand, unlike the Remington, which never cut me, the Panasonic has drawn blood three times. I think what happened is that I used too much pressure trying to get those flat hairs and thereby plowed up a small wrinkle of skin that got through the slots in the trimmer head.<br /><br />Therefore a tip: move the trimmer lightly across the skin surface. Pressure is not very helpful anyway.

Today everything is made in China which has it's reputation for low quality but what people don't realize that with years China manufacturing got a lot better and today you can find same product in low quality and good quality. So when you buy similar products, make sure you buy from known brand from quality perspective like Panasonic in this case.

  3269. I have owned this nose hair trimmer for approximately 2 years. It's amazing to me how this little trimmer can chew through thick tough nose hairs. In that two years I've had to replace the batteries once. I am just now at the point I need a new cutting blade. When dull it will start pulling hair more frequently. When new it instantly shaved the hair so you never feel it. When allowed to get dull it can be uncomfortable.<br /><br />It's ergonomics are excellent. When I was looking for a new trimmer (my prior trimmer of 15+ years had failed) I based my purchase upon the reviews. Upon receipt I was stunned by how petite it appeared. It was so thin and when it powered up seemed to have such a quiet and small motor. To my surprise it was just an example of just how far the technology had advanced. Much smaller units but quiet powerful motors that last very long on a a single set of batteries. I haven't used rechargeable batteries but I'm sure it's performance would also be still very good.<br /><br />The only negative I see is cleaning it out. Since it's so small, so is the collection area. It does rinse quite easily though.<br /><br />As for the blade, I'd say two years is quite admirable. My Braun Shaver requires blade replacement about as frequently. I switch off between blade and shaver often so it's use, although more frequent, is similar. The ER-GN30 has a very small blade so I'm quite surprised it hasn't required replacement sooner than now.<br /><br />All in all I'd say it's a very good purchase. Even at two years I'm still surprised just how well it performs.<br /><br />Hope your experience with the Panasonic ER-GN30 nose hair trimmer is as stellar as mine.

  3361. I, like other excited users, was very pleased with it's performance, it worked great, very close cut, powerful, easy to use, etc... performed great!<br /><br />However! After a few uses(about 8 or so) I heard this horrendous grinding noise and the tip got really hot and even quit working... At first I thought replacing the battery...still the same problem...<br /><br />Long story short, the blades inside the head are spring controlled.... after a few uses the springs just bust out and pushes the blades harshly against the tip head..thus creating the grinding noise that makes the battery and motor wear out..on top of that it inhibits cutting abilities(I tried it 3 times... by now it just rips out hairs if it can catch any...otherwise it's not really working at all).<br /><br />I really wanted this to work.... it's a shame because it performed great the first few times, but like many(read the reviews!!! The good ones are from excited users who had just purchased it... I was like that too...as it performs good...then later, by design it fails....) My unit is not a lone, I have heard this from many other people who have owned this device.... They need to fix this issue by finding out how to retain those springs that hold the blades in.

  3393. Being 6' 2\\" has mostly been a positive, but time does cruel things to a man, and high on the list of those cruelties is the sudden and rapid growth of nose and ear hair. I swear, it was almost overnight that I went from having no such hairs to having hairs long enough to braid, and those poor souls who are shorter than me are stuck looking up at that every time they talk to me.<br /><br />This Panasonic trimmer has been a very effective and simple solution. Do you look and feel stupid using it? Pretty much. But do you look and feel normal walking around in public? Yes! The trimmer is very easy to use, but does include an instruction manual if you prefer specific details. These are handy for properly cleaning and maintaining the unit.<br /><br />The trimmer is small but well constructed. It has 2 speed settings and effectively manages hair in the nose, ears but can also be used on facial hair and eyebrows. It is completely painless. The unit is easily cleaned and includes a small brush for that purpose.<br /><br />This is a well built, high quality trimmer at a very reasonable price. Instead, I am purchasing this $13 unit for its $20 blade to go in my $22 unit. I prefer the other unit because it has a built in vacuum to clean up as it does its job. This one forgoes that feature in favor of a water pass through system. Now if only Panasonic would come up with a unit with both systems and actually sell a reasonably priced blade...

  3507. I guess the central factor is this one appears to be a keeper and I've tried a number of them. It manages to efficiently trim away those most embarrassing gray bristles that seem to grow out of the nostrils like dandelions in an unkempt yard without vibrating at the decibel level of a weedwacker, and it handles the finer follicles that pop out of the ears pretty well, too.<br /><br /> In fact, it is surprisingly quiet for this type of appliance. I have a Norelco all-in-one that is twice as loud and not nearly as effective with quick trims and I also recently bought a Conair model that emits an odor reminiscent of burning hair which does not give one a sense of security when it's jammed in a nostril or aural cavity so, for traveling away, this Panasonic unit will be a constant companion.<br /><br />The one negative in my view, and it's appreciably minor, is the rotary configuration doesn't work as well for eyebrow trimming.

  3534. This hair trimmer is simple to operate and does the job quite well. Just twist the shell cover, separate, pop in one battery, replace the shell cover, twist to lock and you're ready to go. Flip the on/off switch and a low buzzing sound is heard. It removes the nose and ear hairs quite easily. I find it's best to remove the hairs by gently touching the tips and trim each hair gradually rather than trying to remove a hair in one shot, especially the long hairs. Otherwise, the hair may get caught in the blade, pinch, and stop the trimmer. If this happens, remove the shell cover holding the blade, and brush off any hair that's caught. With a little practice, jamming the device can be avoided and the device will operate smoothly. I'm pleased with the results.
  3535. It does the job, seems to cut hairs wherever I need them cut. Happy with it's performance... And it was a very good price.<br />I don't know why some have found this to crap out in a short period of time, as I've been using mine regularly for almost three years, and it still works great!

The nose hair is a little thicker, and it stopped once when a thick hair jammed it up, but it still easier takes care of the nose hair with minimal pulling, as long as I go slow. However, the manufacturer claims it's good for edging beards and mustaches, but when I tried it out, it failed abysmally. Beard and mustache hair is too thick for the trimmer's tiny little blades and motor to handle. It ends up pulling and jamming, and seems like it wouldn't be good for the blades at all, so I stopped using it after one attempt. I'm gonna keep it for ears and nose hair (it'd work on eyebrows too, probably), but saying it can edge beards and mustaches is a fabrication.<br /><br />Also, I was a little disappointed with the feel of the whole thing. I have no comment on battery life as of yet, the original batteries I have in it have yet to give sign they are dying after 3 full uses. Construction feels a little sacrificed on this unit, it doesn't have a very robust feel to it, nor does it carry heft.   3960. having owned several of these devices, i've still not seen anything comparable to the old heavy-duty sharper image \\"turbo groomer 2.0\\" i had ten years ago, but this is about as close as anything out there. it is a tiny little thing, lightly built. it does not have a lot of power and uses only a \\"AA\\" cell. but it is quiet, well designed and it AT LEAST CUTS THE HAIRS, which is more than the others will do. it does not spin very fast, but the blades are well made, they cut efficiently. you can rinse it out with water (ok) or just pop the head off and tap it on a counter (better). it doesn't burn up the battery too fast, it doesn't pull and snag. its easy to hold and seems to catch the hairs more quickly and easily at more angles than the mangroomer and others. you will have to go back and touch up with a regular scissors every now and again, but mostly this will be all you need. i'd still like to see a sturdier, more heavily built, maybe even rechargeable, version of something like this, but for now this is about the best i've seen out there. recommended.

  4052. I would have given this product 5 stars as it trims well and lasts long on the batteries. The problem I have is the product durability. I have purchased 2 of them in the past 6 months. The first one just stopped working after about 2 months of infrequent use (1 – 2 min every other week). I took the head/top off (that contains the blade) and turned it on. The shaft inside the base unit that spins the blade was spinning fine (quiet and fast). When the top was put back on it would not spin. It seemed as though it was seized up or caught on something. I cleaned and dried the head unit and still nothing. I ended up getting it to “work” by bending the blade guards up a little allowing the blade to spin but it made an awful noise and got hot after &#60;30 sec of use. I used it like that for a few weeks (although it was a little unnerving as it sounded like I was shoving a mini wood-chipper up my nose and in my ears). I decided that I would buy another and baby it a little (maybe I was too rough on the last one?). The next one came and it worked great. I would rinse it in water as described in the manual after each use and allowed to dry. After a month, this one seemed to get louder during operation. I opened the top to see if there was some hair/buildup inside. When I opened it, a tiny spring (think of the spring in a retractable pen only shorter) flew out and before I could shut off the water it went down the drain. I didn’t see any spring in the first trimmer I owned so I’m not sure if this is a design change or I just lost the other one without even knowing it. Either way, two trimmers down. I am a glutton for punishment so I am considering purchasing a third on and placing it in a foam lined case and operating it only while wearing white gloves and the drain stopped up.

  4060. I purchased this item because of the great reviews and for the price. I wasn't in the market for the all in one grooming kits. I bought this specifically for trimming nose hairs. I bought this with the idea of having a quick and fast way of trimming my nose hairs.<br /><br />My first initial reaction when I had unboxed this, was this thing was light and felt cheap. The plastic body feels like it's made of cheap china plastic that would break or crack on your first accidental drop on a hard floor. The light weight does make it a plus if you need to spend a considerable amount of time trimming so your hand or arm doesn't get tired. Taking it apart and putting it back together is very simple with a twist and lock/unlock system. The concept to remove or install the head of the trimmer or the battery compartment is the same.<br /><br />I would like to point out that the picture displaying the vortex cleaning system is a stream of water coming into the tip and exiting the side hole. In all reality the trimmer is submerged a stream of water coming out of the faucet. It's almost next to impossible to get a good steady stream of water to flush it out as it is depicted. I just turned on my faucet and stuck it underneath until I saw water coming out of the side port for a few seconds to clean it out.<br /><br />If you are worried about water affecting the unit, water didn't manage to find a way into the unit while I was cleaning it. I would be worried about it's water resistant properties as time goes by and parts wear down. Even though it advertises on their internet site for use in the shower, I wouldn't try it simply because a product at the price they sell it for usually isn't built to last. Also, electronics + water is usually bad. In case it doesn't last, the product is backed by a two year warranty which is pretty impressive than what most manufactures offer.<br /><br />I have to say that it lacked a little bit in it's performance. This is my first time using a product like this, so I'm not sure if the sound of it catching a random thick hair and cutting it caught me off guard and startled me or if it caught a hair and had slight trouble cutting it. With the exception of those few moments, it cut well. I did have a problem where I had to move it around a lot and in a lot of different angles to get the hairs I felt like the unit missed. I would attribute my difficulty to getting all the hairs to the size of my nostrils compared to most. It did feel fairly comfortable in my hand while I was using it. I only used the product once and haven't used it again. I prefer using my specialized scissors I can use to manually trim hairs.<br /><br />Even though this product isn't really for me, the combination of the warranty, the ability of using it with water / getting it wet, performance, and for the price, I would say this is a good buy for anyone who needs to trim some hair in their nose or ear without sticking sharp objects in it. It also works for people on the go or someone who doesn't have access to a mirror.using a product like this, so I'm not sure if the sound of it catching a random thick hair and cutting it caught me off guard and startled me or if it caught a hair and had slight trouble cutting it. With the exception of those few moments, it cut well. I did have a problem where I had to move it around a lot and in a lot of different angles to get the hairs I felt like the unit missed. I would attribute my difficulty to getting all the hairs to the size of my nostrils compared to most. It did feel fairly comfortable in my hand while I was using it. I only used the product once and haven't used it again. I prefer using my specialized scissors I can use to manually trim hairs.<br /><br />Even though this product isn't really for me, the combination of the warranty, the ability of using it with water / getting it wet, performance, and for the price, I would say this is a good buy for anyone who needs to trim some hair in their nose or ear without sticking sharp objects in it. It also works for people on the go or someone who doesn't have access to a mirror.

My last trimmer was one of those cheap Avon/Sharper Image ones and this one works much better and costs the same amount. Can't go wrong with this product.
  4144. well, worked as it shd, comfortable using it as comparable to those that i used/owned in the past. highly recommended

  4157. Been using this trimmer since 15 December 2012, and it's performance is awesome.<br /><br />This little machine does its job well and quietly, albeit there is minimal buzzing noise, which is generally acceptable. First time trying out a nose trimmer, and surprisingly there wasn't any slightest level of discomfort. Trimming nose hair is pretty quick. Took me less than 2 minutes each trimming session. This trimmer is also very easy to operate and disassemble to clean.<br /><br />You may even use it to trim hair at other parts of your body, for instance, eyebrows, bread, sideburn.<br /><br />The only downfall would be the trimmed nose hair would be left inside the nose. This is just a minor issue, which apparently Panasonic designed the 'Panasonic ER430K' with a vacuum system to address it.<br /><br />Will monitor it's durability and update this review in future.<br /><br />All in all, this is a product that will satisfy your trimming needs. Excellent trimmer!<br />-------------------------------------------------<br />Update:<br />After a year of infrequent usage (once every 2 weeks or so), the trimmer fails to work well and it tugs on your nose hair. Really uncomfortable. From what I read in the comments, this is due to the malfunctioning springs inside the little blade. The damaged springs could be a result of my OCD habit of disassembling the trimmer into its components for thoroughly cleaning. It is weird that Panasonic doesn't sell replacement blades. Perhaps they would prefer to make a larger profit by sell entirely new units instead of replacement blades.<br /><br />The second issue is, the seal at the battery compartment is not up to standard. I did not soak the trimmer in water, cleaned the trimmer as instructed, and yet water managed to seep inside the battery compartment. Now there is a faint weird smell permeating from the trimmer whenever I change the battery.<br /><br />Wouldn't recommend this product at all, unless Panasonic comes up with replacement blades and improves on the seal.
  4158. The trimmer I just ordered had a battery with an expiration date of 2009. Since the lifespan of the battery is about 5 - 7 years, the trimmer was probably made between 2002 - 2004.<br /><br />Even though it's an old one, it still works great. Very gentle while cutting the nose hairs close to the skin. Definitely five stars.

  4214. To quote another reviewer because the same thing happened to me after several uses: &#34;After a few uses(about 8 or so) I heard this horrendous grinding noise and the tip got really hot and even quit working... At first I thought replacing the battery...still the same problem... Long story short, the blades inside the head are spring controlled.... after a few uses the springs just bust out and pushes the blades harshly against the tip head..thus creating the grinding noise that makes the battery and motor wear out..on top of that it inhibits cutting abilities(I tried it 3 times... by now it just rips out hairs if it can catch any...otherwise it's not really working at all).&#34;

I think if you rinse/dry it after each use it should last 2-4 years or more. (hear a tip on how I cleaned my old Wahl trimmer and it should work for this trimmer also) You will need a small cup,white vinegar, pour small amount in to cup just enough to soak silver tip/spinning blade let soak for 30min to 2hrs depending on how dirty it is, rinse off with hot hater/maybe brush off with old toothbrush & dry off.

  4580. Better than sliced bread! When you hit 40 this device is mandatory. Buy a magnifying glass while your at it.
  4581. Please note: I intend to supplement this review when I have more time.<br /><br />I just received unit yesterday, read the manual, used it only once, but it cut nose hairs very well.<br /><br />I've owned two other nose trimmers over the years. The first was rotary and it worked but not all that efficiently.<br />The second contained horizontal blades and I felt the unit was a pain and was not good at all at clipping the nose hairs-it was a tedious process as well as irritated the skin surrounding my nostrils-for that reason, I would recommend only rotary trimmer for nose. This is a rotary unit.<br /><br />Obviously, I am not able to comment on longevity, but unit is warranted for 2 years parts and labor. That's great!<br /><br />Tips I can pass on based upon my reading of manual, telephone conversation with Panasonic, and use:<br /><br />1 Manual should definitely be read thoroughly;<br /><br />2. However, the manual did not cover all my inquiries so I contacted Panasonic;<br /><br />3 There are some intermediate positions but they do not have any function-one should either set the dial at '0' to use the unit or on 'faucet' for water cleaning;<br /><br />4. When you are able to discern from the manual how to remove the outer blade (which contains the inner blade) use the supplied cleaning brush to clean both off;<br /><br />5. Re re-inserting the inner blade into the outer blade-just push it in gently, but there is no way to 'lock' it in AFAIK, so no real proper orientation or grooves to slide into-don't worry about it;<br /><br />6. When one wants to connect the outer blade unit to the base unit, press down on outer blade once you have (by feel) rotated it to proper orientation, and, importantly, turn it clockwise and do apply some considerable force until you hear it 'snap' tight-keep on turning until you hear a pronounced snap and will go no further. At that time, you will see the solitary index mark on the base of the outer blade unit is aligned with theindex mark on the blue dial. If you don't do this the unit may start to come apart when turned on-this happened to me. So if you are going to mess with removing and brushing the blades be sure that you have properly secured them to the base unit, and test run it first before inserting in any area to be trimmed.<br /><br />At this price point, this is the best that I've found thus far and it's well worth the cost. I was pleasantly surprised with this unit's clipping ability. It definitely deserves 5-Stars!

  4755. It's a nose trimmer; There are only two kinds, manual and automatic, and this is of the automatic flavor. Manual nose trimmers appeal to those who may use DE razors (like me) but often get horribly reviewed because they end up grabbing and tugging like a vice rather than simply scrubbing away.<br /><br />Opting for automatic, I got this one, as there isn't many other options out there. It works fine, is built to be washed (thank god - I had another one that got rotted smelling quickly because it wasn't designed to be cleaned in any simple manner), and it cleans hairs out if you give it the time to do so and swish it around enough. Final verdict? If you have long nose hairs (whether or not they show themselves beyond your nostrils) then this is a fine way to clear them away.

  4797. Some other trimmers can make you feel like Arnold in that scene from the original Total Recall, in which he extracts a homing device from somewhere in his upper nostril. This isn't one of those trimmers; its shape prevents you from exploring the nether regions of your sinus cavities. However, if you have deep nostrils (Who really knows this about themselves?), you might want to consider something with a longer end.<br /><br />Look at this product closely. Zoom in. The tip's small openings are somewhat less effective than an exposed cutting mechanism, but also less painful. It takes some finessing to get all of the hairs, but with a little patience, it happens. This product isn't meant for longer hair, but it catches stubble easily, so use it every day or two, for a minute or two, and you'll be happy with the results.
  4798. ... but here I am anyways. I have been using a Remington brand trimmer for the last few years but always dreaded it. It had a brass head on it which was pretty thick. This translated into hairs not getting trimmed as close as I'd like. It also had a problem of corrosion buildup on the battery contacts, resulting in a power drop to the motor. This meant that I'd always have to keep a super fresh battery in it, and was constantly dealing with low motor speeds and pulled hairs. Ouch.<br /><br />This one is a very nice improvement. The trimmer head is a thinner metal, so the hairs get trimmed much shorter. It also doesn't have the problem of corrosion buildup on the battery contacts, so I always get fast speeds. There isn't a lot in day to day life that's worse than pulled nose hairs and I'm happy to say that I am now free of that experience. It's also a nice touch that you can open up a port to help water flow through and rinse this out. It's good on ear hairs and trimming up facial hair, as well. Ah, the joys of aging.

Be careful when cleaning the tip head which comes off with a twist, you don't want to damage the blade or plastic retaining clip. These tend to last me about 3-4 years but would probably last more if I didn't drop it. I want to give it 4.5 but not quite 5 since I find the power a bit weak, perfect for me but I can see it having some difficulty with thick coarse hair. Use a good quality battery for optimal results.

  4934. I bought this specifically for nose hair, but it's not the simple solution I hoped for. The manufacturer instructions actually say not to put the trimmer into the nostril! I found out why.<br /><br />First time in, I was rooting around inside my nose hoping that when I pulled the device out, all the hair would be gone (a reasonable expectation, I thought). Instead, half the hairs were still there, particularly the hairs that hug the nostril wall. So I went back in, closer to the sides of the nostril this time, and cleaned out as many more hairs as I could bare. (The trimmed hairs fly into your nose and make your eyes water, it's about as pleasant as chopping an onion.)<br /><br />The next day I woke up and blew my nose only to find blood all over the tissue, from both nostrils. Obviously the blade had trimmed more than just the hairs in there. I felt mild stinging in my nose for the next few days while it healed.<br /><br />Lesson learned: this trimmer is for people who have nose hair growing _beyond_ the nostril opening. Proceed with caution, don't let the tip of the trimmer touch any skin. And most importantly, don't expect this device to completely eliminate your nose hairs, because it won't.
  4935. Purchased this Panasonic Hair Trimmer in June, 2012. Used very infrequently at 2nd home....perhaps three times. Unit no longer works, regardless of how many new batteries I put in it.
