  4936. When I opened the smiling box, my girlfriend seemed way more excited about this than I was. I had an older model Panasonic for about five years that finally burned out on the nose and ear puberty I've been combatting since I hit my 30's, so I feel good about the reliability of this one.<br /><br />It cuts quickly and without tugging out the nostril roots, which can make a burly man tear up something fierce. From experience, if you find your nose trimmer pulling, it's time to replace or charge the battery.<br /><br />I like the washout feature: I've gotten into the habit of running this in my head holes while I'm waiting for the water to heat up in the shower and flush it out before getting to the latherwork. I'll probably like this feature a lot more once cold and flu season arrives: I've always anguished when I couldn't trim my nostrils when suffering a stuffy nose.

You'd have to do some seriously mean things to it to break it. Works wet just as good as it does dry. The cutting blade is safely hidden, and the only way you will potentially nick yourself is if you crush the unit against your skin. Cleaning is a charm, just flip the ring to pass through mode, put under a faucet, and turn on. Every week or two pop open and take a brush to the blade.<br /><br />I'm powering this with a Sanyo Eneloop AA battery. It hasn't had any problems with pulling of hairs or any of the other issues people have described when using rechargeables, but YMMV. It may just be that my facial hair isn't as thick as theirs.<br /><br />As a man who no longer has to worry about the walrus nose hair look, I found this to be a very worthwhile purchase, especially as cheap as it is price wise.

  5347. I've had a nose hair trimmer before and wasn't pleased with it, as it seemed like it did more pulling than trimming, so it mostly stayed in the drawer and I used a pair of scissors. The Panasonic was on sale on Amazon, on a Lightning Deal, so I figured I'd give it a shot.<br /><br />I'm not going to extol its virtues to the skies or pretend that it's any more than what it is: an inexpensive gadget that basically does just one thing and does it pretty well. It gets the job done, with more cutting than pulling (but still the occasional &#34;ouch&#34; every now and then, so not perfect), and it's easy to clean.<br /><br />The trimmer runs on a single AA battery. The manufacturer claims 90 minutes of battery life, a claim I take with a grain of salt, but the battery life is still strong after several uses, so clearly not something I'm going to have to change every trim or two.<br /><br />The bottom line is that it's reasonably priced and gets the job done. I do have some concerns about the long-term effectiveness of the trimmer but for now, anyway, it's fine and I can recommend it.

  5537. Original review:<br />After trying a couple other nose trimmers out there, this one proved to be the best. While others may have been a bit more powerful, they also vibrated too much and pulled the nose hair, which was extremely painful.<br /><br />This trimmer has almost no vibration (a good sign in small electric motors) and does not pull at all. The fact that it's washable with soap and water is a great feature, which helps avoid infection. Overall it's an excellent product.<br /><br />P.S. Note that this trimmer is about 30% smaller than it looks in some of these pictures, like the one's held up to the man's face. This actually might work in its favor, to get to hard-to-reach places.<br /><br />Update 6/29/14:<br />Well now I've bought two of these, and both of the motors have turned out to be garbage. In both cases they worked fine at first, but they soon began making whirring noises which became louder and louder. Eventually they ground to a halt. New batteries didn't help; they were simply drained of energy very quickly. More rubbish for the trash heap. I'd say it's the fault of the Chinese for making such worthless products; then again if we didn't continue to buy their trash, this would quickly become much, much less of a problem.

  5576. I purchased this nose hair trimmer in February. At first, it worked ok but not great. Within a month, it was working sporadically. I should have returned it then, but I figured that I would just put up with a mediocre piece of equipment, which I did until around a month ago (May). At that time, it stopped working, but after around a week, I tried it again, and it worked, albeit, barely. At this point (June 24), it doesn't work at all. I tried to return it, only to find that I couldn't. I buy a lot through Amazon. This is the first time, after many thousands of dollars of purchases, that I really feel that I got ripped off. I took excellent care of the device. I used as instructed. I never dropped it -- not once. And I am left holding the bag. The only part that is ok is that I guess I can afford the loss.<br /><br />Amazon has a reputation of customer satisfaction. While the item was not good, Amazon really stepped up to the plate. I wrote an email to Amazon and within 24 hours, I was issued a refund.<br /><br />My conclusions: I would not recommend the item to anyone. I do strongly recommend Amazon. They stand behind the products more than anyone else on the internet.

We both have never used nose hair trimmers before so it is hard for basis of comparison but based on the experience with this product, my husband thought they were decent, but said he pushed them on his skin and they nicked him a little, but thought that if he was careful they seemed to get the job done as he expected.<br /><br />When I tried them I noticed that they seemed to warm up quickly, perhaps from being previously used by my husband. Since I had never used them I needed to use them longer than if I was just maintaining. So perhaps if I just use them for touch ups they won't get as hot. I also felt that they completed the job as expected to trim not completely remove the hair as if using a razor.<br /><br />I will post again after using them for a longer period of time, but I wanted to get our initial impression out there for those trying to make a decision.
  5582. Cutting head is poor quality. Have to bang on unit to get it to spin up to speed then fades again after a few hairs. Yanks a few hairs out. Worked better for few months but now replacing.

  5658. Note: I purchased this for my husband and he's extremely pleased with it. Here's his feedback:<br /><br />When I think of Panasonic I'm thinking plasma TVs and maybe rice cookers, not nose trimmers. The ER-GN30 is the first trimmer that I have been truly pleased with. It is firm in the hand; very good build quality and just a very well thought out product. This product does not try to be the Swiss army knife of trimmers - nose and ears are its territory. Oh, and the knives are very sharp and precise - nose and ear trimming are not marathon events - short sprint and you're done. Your first trimming session will probably be longer than it needs to be, until you see how efficient this weed whacker is. One other feature I appreciate is that the unit does not sound like a jet engine when you are trimming your ears. The trimmer motor is one of the quietest ones that I have used. The unit is easily \\"wash/rinse\\" able; set it on the counter for an hour and you can toss in your travel bag. Although the build is sturdy, I wouldn't trust it in soft checked luggage. I never check luggage, but that may be changing :-) For home use or road warriors, this is a very dependable companion.

  5663. I bought it because of good reviews. I realized why it was good once it arrived. That is, the thickness of the metal protector around the blade, while hard, is very thin. This makes it cut as close as a shave. I saw at a local store other trimmers at a similar price but these all had a much thicker metal end. Talking here about the the thickness of the walls of the metal tube, not about the diameter.<br />One tip though. When you put the batteries in - roll them several times while they are inside. This will strip the patina off the contacts. Otherwise the unit may have some trouble starting. This is totally normal for any new electrical &#34;thing&#34; where the contact surfaces are completely polished.

  5737. Note, I only use this product for my nose and ears.<br /><br />For years I've used scissors to cut my nose hairs, which has lead to cuts and nicks. I decided to finally get a trimmer when an ear hair spouted out and made me contemplate my own mortality. I am getting older now and I must combat this with full force. So I was searching through nose trimmers and couldn’t settle on one. I've tried other versions in the past and it was always painful. I decided to torture myself by reading the reviews; I for one don’t play the odds, I see 95 five star ratings and pay more attention to the one negative. Of course I’d get the one that doesn’t work or malfunctions and rips part of your nose off. Alas I settled on this gem solely on the price.<br /><br />Pros: The price, seriously we can all afford $12 bucks. Also, it only works on one battery, so you’re not going to be breaking the bank on it. The comfort with it is the best, a day later and I have no red marks or cut skin. I can rub my nose freely without fear of a sharp unforgiving pain, one that I’m sure can only be rivaled to childbirth.<br /><br />Cons: It works on a battery. ‘Now wait, didn’t you list that as a pro?’ Yes sure did, thanks for paying attention. Unfortunately this means the pain and anguish of dying battery will one day lead to an inevitable bloodbath. Ok, more like a sharp pain and a realization to throw the battery out.<br /><br />Overall: Buy it, it works comfortably and it’s cheap, can’t ask for much more.
  5738. I tried this thing out and it will cut hair, at least for now.<br /><br />All the parts on the product that I could see look very cheap. The removeable blade is made of part plastic and part metal (the metal part does the actual cutting). This blade assembly looks awfully flimsy. I wouldn't expect it to last very long. The handle of the unit looks like it's made of cheap plastic and attaches to the rest of the unit in a cheap way. I'll be surprised if the handle even stays attached for very long.<br /><br />I don't think I would recommend buying it at all. I use rechargeable batteries and they seem to work just fine.<br /><br />The trimmer is pretty quiet, does a good trim on nose hair, the errant eyebrow hairs, inside my deep chin dimple and the occasional trim around the edge of my ears.   6065. I'm not going to give it 5 stars until I've had it for a good while. That's because I've had about 4 different brands of &#34;personal&#34; trimmers that all started out great but then failed within a few months. So, I like how it performs, I like how easy it is to clean...you just turn the dial at the top which opens a port where water can be discharged after flowing into the tip, or flow water into the port and it's discharged out through the tip. That's a cool feature. It also does what it's supposed to do, cut nose hair, without any problem. So, let's just see if it lasts.

  6082. I've bought about 4 of these. Great for the price and works efficiently.<br /><br />Note of warning. If you drop it, and one of the the &#34;blade&#34; guards bends inward, you'd have to get another trimmer. The blade is very thin and spins around inside the blade guard. If one of the metal guards bends inward to the blade....good luck getting it out. It makes a loud grinding nose as the blade hits the guard and doesn't cut well after that. So just keep the plastic guard on top of the trimmer and don't drop it. Great trimmer then. : )

  6119. I'm sure most people are familiar with the cheap, $5 or less nose hair trimmers that fall apart and rip the hairs out. Often people can go through several of these types of trimmers in a year and not think much about it. Save yourself the time and aggravation and just get a decent nose hair trimmer. The Panasonic ER-GN30-K Vortex is just the right one to consider. At around $15 it won't break the bank but at the same time is is made with far more attention to quality and utility. The trimmer is a wet/dry model that with a simple turn of the head will shave with wet (i.e. in the shower or at the sink) or dry. The cutting action is far superior to cheaper models, with hair being caught and ripped out far less often. In fact in over a month of use I can only think of one time a hair got yanked out by this trimmer, an outstanding track record. My only worry is that while the device is clearly of higher quality than the cheap throwaways I have used in the past, it does seem to utilize the same type of cutting mechanism, and I worry that in time this may begin to rip out hairs just as frequently as cheaper trimmers. That said, it is clear that even if this trimmer does lose it's edge, it will still have lasted longer by far than it's cheaper brethren and in the meantime I would have had a far superior trimming experience. Due to the concern over long-term durability, I give this four stars, but still recommend this product highly.

  6146. This product works great, just be careful how you use it. Using it to trim facial hair from side burns, eyebrows, and other surface areas is fine. I used this to trim nose hair and I found out the hard way, the hair in your nose is there for a reason. I must say I am a little embarrassed, but if one person can avoid my experience that's ok. Evidently, I was not as careful as I should have been and remove to much or to close or both. About a week after I used this product to remove my nose hairs, my lymph glands in my neck swelled. I cannot be 100% this was the cause, but after speaking with health professionals, they also believe it could have been. This waxing and waning of my glands continued for a month. I first time they swelled, the glands were so tender, I didn't want to touch my neck. Then they would go down and in a couple of days swell again. Each time the pain would decrease. But, this continued for a whole month. My doctor gave my an antibiotic, but fornutately said not to use unless I really needed it. I went to my trusted Health Food store and purchased coloidal silver. I had worked so hard to get my intestinal flora in good shape, I didn't want to kill the good bacteria, if I could avoid it. Anyway, it worked. No antibiotic. Just BEcareful! Don't be stupid like I was because I must say I was a little scared. I will go back to using scissors for trimming nose hairs!

  6152. I've tried a few trimmers and most always with disappointing results. Most all of them have a cheap feel to them and tend to be a bit loud (cheap motors). The Vortex is definitely an exception and the best I've seen so far.<br /><br />Unique to the Vortex is a spinning cutter and cone shape, which both contribute towards its better than average job. Contrary to other devices of this kind, it has a powerful, smooth running and quiet motor. That is very unusual with trimmers, and a welcome change.<br /><br />Another attribute of the Vortex that is different, yet at the same time brilliant, is a small ring near the cone tip that when twisted, opens a small hole where you can run water through to clean it. The water runs out of the cone tip and takes with it any debris inside the cone cutter. I add an extra measure by substituting some isopropyl alcohol for the water and cleaning with that. I'm not sure if this is recommended, but I feel it does a better job keeping it clean.<br /><br />All in all, this one comes highly recommended.
